p: Free radical scavenging activity was assessed using a modified version of the method proposed by Cheng, et al. [ 54] ( n = 4–6 per group). In brief, 100 μL of sample extracts (4, 20, 100, 500, 2500 μg/mL) or isolated compounds (10, 25, 50, 100, 200 μM) dissolved in 50% ethanol were added to 100 μL of 0.2 mM DPPH (Fisher Scientific, Leicestershire, UK) solution, reaching a final concentration of 0.1 mM DPPH. Each reaction mixture was shaken for five seconds and left to stand for 30 min in the dark at 25 °C. The absorbance of each mixture was measured at 515 nm against a blank (50% ethanol) using a SpectraMax i3x Microplate spectrophotometer (Molecular devices). The inhibition rate of DPPH radicals was calculated as follows: DPPH inhibition rate (%) = (1 − [A sample − A blank]/[A control − A blank]) × 100
